timePeriods.name: Akkadian Empire
timePeriods.description: The first ancient empire of Mesopotamia, founded by Sargon of Akkad.

timePeriods.name: Egyptian Empire (New Kingdom)
timePeriods.description: The period of Egypt's greatest power and prosperity, including the reigns of Tutankhamun and Ramses II.

timePeriods.name: Persian Empire (Achaemenid)
timePeriods.description: An ancient empire founded by Cyrus the Great, known for its tolerance and efficient administration.

timePeriods.name: Macedonian Empire
timePeriods.description: Empire founded by Alexander the Great, stretching from Greece to India.

timePeriods.name: Roman Empire
timePeriods.description: The dominant power in Europe and the Mediterranean for centuries; transitioned from Republic to Empire under Augustus.

timePeriods.name: Byzantine Empire
timePeriods.description: The Eastern Roman Empire, lasting over a thousand years after the fall of Rome.

timePeriods.name: Mongol Empire
timePeriods.description: The largest contiguous empire in history, founded by Genghis Khan.

timePeriods.name: Ottoman Empire
timePeriods.description: A powerful Islamic empire that controlled much of Southeast Europe, Western Asia, and North Africa.

timePeriods.name: British Empire
timePeriods.description: The largest empire in history, with colonies and territories on every continent.

timePeriods.name: Holy Roman Empire
timePeriods.description: A multi-ethnic complex of territories in central Europe that developed during the early Middle Ages.

timePeriods.name: Greco-Persian Wars
timePeriods.description: A series of conflicts between the Persian Empire and various Greek city-states including Athens and Sparta.

timePeriods.name: Peloponnesian War
timePeriods.description: A war fought between Athens and Sparta that shifted the balance of power in ancient Greece.

timePeriods.name: Punic Wars
timePeriods.description: A series of three wars fought between Rome and Carthage, culminating in the destruction of Carthage.

timePeriods.name: Hundred Years' War
timePeriods.description: A prolonged conflict between England and France over the French throne and territorial claims.

timePeriods.name: Thirty Years' War
timePeriods.description: A religious and political conflict primarily fought in Central Europe, devastating the Holy Roman Empire.

timePeriods.name: Napoleonic Wars
timePeriods.description: A series of wars involving Napoleon's French Empire against various European coalitions.

timePeriods.name: American Civil War
timePeriods.description: A civil war in the United States between the Union and Confederate states primarily over slavery.

timePeriods.name: World War I
timePeriods.description: A global war centered in Europe, triggered by the assassination of Archduke Franz Ferdinand.

timePeriods.name: World War II
timePeriods.description: A global war involving most of the world's nations, resulting in an Allied victory and the foundation of the UN.

timePeriods.name: Cold War
timePeriods.description: A prolonged geopolitical and ideological conflict between the United States and the Soviet Union.

timePeriods.name: Stone Age
timePeriods.description: The prehistoric period characterized by the use of stone tools before the development of metalworking.

timePeriods.name: Bronze Age
timePeriods.description: A period marked by the use of bronze for tools and weapons, and the rise of early civilizations like Mesopotamia and Egypt.

timePeriods.name: Iron Age
timePeriods.description: Characterized by the widespread use of iron tools and weapons, and the development of complex societies.

timePeriods.name: Classical Antiquity
timePeriods.description: An era of Greek and Roman cultural dominance in the Mediterranean and Europe.

timePeriods.name: Middle Ages
timePeriods.description: The period from the fall of the Western Roman Empire to the beginning of the Renaissance and Age of Exploration.

timePeriods.name: Renaissance
timePeriods.description: A cultural movement centered in Europe, marked by revival in art, science, and classical learning.

timePeriods.name: Early Modern Period
timePeriods.description: The period marked by exploration, colonization, and the rise of early nation-states.

timePeriods.name: Modern Era
timePeriods.description: A time of revolutions, industrialization, and major global conflicts including the World Wars.

timePeriods.name: Contemporary Period
timePeriods.description: The post-World War II era, characterized by rapid technological advancement, globalization, and geopolitical tension.
